speaker: Beth
text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Beth.

speaker: Neil
text: And I'm Neil. Today we're going to talk about climate change and how it can affect people's mental health. Natural disasters and the impacts of climate change can be stressful. Isn't that right, Beth?

speaker: Beth
text: Yeah, definitely. In today's episode we're going to find out about how people can protect their mental health from the impacts of climate change. We'll be hearing from a psychiatry expert and a man who survived a wildfire and helped rebuild his town.

speaker: Neil
text: But first, Beth, I have a question for you. Scientists aren't always sure whether natural disasters like floods and wildfires are as a result of human-caused climate change. But in January 2025, big wildfires affected big parts of Los Angeles in California. But according to research organisation World Weather Attribution, human-caused climate change made the fires:

speaker: Neil
text: a)    10% more likely

speaker: Neil
text: b)    35% more likely

speaker: Neil
text: c)    20% less likely

speaker: Beth
text: Erm… I'm going to say 10% more likely.

speaker: Neil
text: OK. Well, we'll find out the answer at the end of the programme. Now, natural disasters like floods and wildfires can destroy homes and communities.

speaker: traumaTrauma
text: People who live in areas affected by natural disasters can often experience climate trauma. Trauma is what we call the very bad and long-lasting emotional effects of an event or experience.

speaker: Neil
text: Professor Jyoti Mishra is an expert in climate trauma at the University of California. She explained more about the condition to Graihagh Jackson, host of BBC World Service programme, The Climate Question.

speaker: trauma traumatrauma
text: Climate trauma is not an individual trauma, it's a community-wide trauma which really requires community-wide healing.

speaker: struck byreknits
text: Yeah, I'm really struck by what you've said about the fact that it's whole communities that are affected, not individuals, but also part of the solution is about the community and how it rebuilds and reknits together.

speaker: resilient.
text: Absolutely, yes. So, we've found that individuals who have a greater sense of positive support from their family and a greater sense of meaningful connection with their community — they are in general more resilient.

speaker: Beth
text: Jyoti's research on climate trauma has found that it affects communities rather than individuals.

speaker: struck bystruck by
text: Host of the programme Graihagh Jackson is struck by what Jyoti says. If you're struck by an idea, you find it particularly interesting or impressive.

speaker: reknits togetherclose-knit
text: Graihagh says that part of the solution to climate trauma could be in how the community reknits together. This means how the social connections in a community are restored. We can often describe a community as close-knit, which means everyone helps and supports each other.

speaker: resilient resilient
text: Jyoti explains that having a strong community also helps reduce or heal climate trauma. She says that research has found that people who have a strong community are more resilient when bad things, like natural disasters, happen. If you're resilient, you're able to get better more easily after something difficult or bad happens.

speaker: Beth
text: One person who had to be resilient is Brad Sherwood. He survived a wildfire in Northern California in 2017 called the Tubbs fire, but when he returned home, his neighbourhood was destroyed.

speaker: Neil
text: Brad started to volunteer for a local support network called After the Fire to try to rebuild his community, as he explained to BBC World Service programme, The Climate Question.

speaker: silver liningresilient hurdle
text: The silver lining in all this — I mean, if it wasn't for the Tubbs fire, we wouldn't be working as a community right now to build a new community plaza. We were a close community before the Tubbs, but afterwards we are so much stronger and resilient. And I think our children are as well. They can jump over any hurdle.

speaker: silver liningsilver lining
text: Brad says that the work to rebuild and improve his community is the silver lining to the fire. The expression silver lining means a positive thing that comes from a negative situation.

speaker: jump over any hurdle. hurdles
text: Brad's community became more resilient after the fire, including the children. He says that they can jump over any hurdle. We can describe challenges or difficult things in life as hurdles.

speaker: Beth
text: And it's quite inspiring, I think, to hear how Brad has taken a bad situation and tried to stay resilient. Now, the organisation Brad volunteers for, After the Fire, are helping those impacted by the fires in LA in January.

speaker: Neil
text: Which reminds me, I asked you, Beth, about the impacts of human-made climate change on the wildfires in LA in January.

speaker: Beth
text: And I said 10% more likely.

speaker: Neil
text: Which was, I'm afraid, the wrong answer. It was actually 35%.

speaker: trauma
text: Wow. OK. Well, let's recap the vocabulary we've learnt, starting with trauma, which is what we call the very bad and long-lasting emotional effects of an event or experience.

speaker: struck by
text: If you're struck by an idea or something someone has said, you find it particularly interesting or impressive.

speaker: reknits togetherclose-knit
text: If a community reknits together, it becomes closer again. And a close-knit community is where everyone looks after each other.

speaker: Resilient
text: Resilient means able to get better more easily when bad things happen.

speaker: silver lining
text: A silver lining is a positive thing that comes from a negative situation.

speaker: hurdles
text: And we can describe challenges or difficult things in life as hurdles.

speaker: Beth
text: Once again, our six minutes are up, but why not try the interactive quiz on our website to test what you've learned, and we have a free worksheet as well. Just visit bbclearningenglish.com.

text: Thanks for listening and goodbye!
